This is such an important lesson to anyone following along who's either a mixer or especially a mastering engineer. You can send someone spiraling with doubt based off of one comment, perhaps your own limited understanding of the material. 

Even the way you phrase something can make all the difference. "Hey AJ, I hear what you're going for and I love it, but I think there's room for the bass to hit harder if you can back off the levels. author: oaklandmatt
content:
Haha just relaying my experience. If you're sending to a mastering engineer it's a whole different conversation.

Always think about what you're trying to accomplish at any given stage. Then go after that goal. 

I used to spend too much time on sonics in writing sessions. I should have been solely focused on finding emotional magic. Now  I am just trying to inspire the artists and writers around me, I'll deal with the sonics later. Much better results.

I also used to fully mix-as-I-go, which painted me into a corner with gain staging and eq. Now when I get to the end of the process, I often pull things back and rebuild my levels so there's headroom and I can make that exciting production translate.

Different approaches for different parts of the process.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Gonna circle back with more later, but this is my 2 cents (I started mastering with zero clients about 9 months ago)...

Get over your fear/insecurity/weirdness of not having a portfolio. Go fuck it mode. You need to have a ton of contacts. Take a lot of shots. Of course I have no idea about what you are doing currently...but zero people I've ever talked to in this situation have taken enough shots. "I reached out to 5 people this week"...no. HUNDREDS. Most people will ignore you. But just keep going. Watch a Goggins video before you start or something haha

Really think about the experience of working with you. Is it amazing? Is it easy? Is your communication, care, intention incredible? Even things like how files are named/delivered/etc matters. You can only be as good as you are at mixing until you get more reps. But you can control how you interact and the professionalism and confidence you can inspire on the other side.

If someone lets you mix a song...are they coming back? They need to if you are going to have a business doing this!

Sorry to be prescriptive here...but I've seen this question asked of me enough to know that it's so so hugely about just brutal persistence in many aspects, assuming you have talent, etc to do the actual thing.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Honestly, that line is a bit over blown. It’s more “oh the chorus is louder, let’s knock it back a click or two on the input so it doesn’t distort”

We were usually recording songs in fairly small sections, making sure to get the details right. There wasn’t a lot of jedi like fader riding. On very rare occasions if I knew there was going to be a huge dynamic shift I’d reach out and grab the output fader, but I can probably count on one hand how many times I’ve had to do that.

We were fairly conservative on the 1176 on the way in, largely cause you can’t un crunch a vocal that’s been over compressed, but once the vocal was in PT it would be hit by just irresponsible levels of compression and limiting. Like goes against how virtually every “expert” online would tell you how to do it. Most people would tell you the solo’d tracks would sound bad, but as part of the song their impact is objectively unarguable

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
.
Assuming we're talking about fairly typical rock, pop and Hip Hop then this 3 part strategy covers a lot of ground

1) Make sure the EQ is as balanced as you can get it - most of your perceived loudness comes from the arrangement and mid range focus (2k to 8k). Too much low end will sound bad when you limit. Make sure the relationship between 80, 160 and 320 makes sense (think of them a little like fundamental, 1st and 2nd harmonic).

2) Consider shaving snare transients (and maybe kick transients) with a clipper. This spreads that peak energy harmonically across the spectrum, keeping energy, hiding in the noisey nature of snares and lets the limiter work less hard (I like SIR Standardclip - $25, great metering and responds intuitively)

3) Pro-L2 on the settings below is a great start point for clean and predictable limiting, raising input gain until you get the desired level

author: Slow Hand
content:
It's a big topic, but gain staging is about finding the optimal amount of gain at every stage of the recording and mixing process.

Good gain staging allows you to get the best fidelity out of a recording by preventing things from creating unwanted distortion or amplifying unwanted noise. **OR** if you are *seeking* some distortion and compression it's about turning up the gain enough to give you the amount that you're seeking from your tools.

Gain staging is something to be considered at all steps of the production process. For example:

*1. How loud is an amplifier turned up in the room? Is the microphone being blow out by it?

2. How high is the gain on a microphone preamp and is it at risk of clipping if the performer plays loudly?

3. Is the gain so low that when I turn a signal up later on the noise floor will rise with it?

4. If I'm recording to tape, am I recording quiet enough that it won't saturate the signal, or do I want for the signal to slam the tape and be saturated?

5. How loud is an individual channel in a DAW? Is it making the channel clip?

6. How loud is a signal that's being sent into a piece of hardware or a plugin? Am I distorting the circuitry at all?

7. Is my signal coming in so hot that it makes a compressor react way too hard?

8. How loud is the entire track I'm mixing? Is the limiter crushing the dynamics in an unwanted way? Or am I hitting it just with just enough level to get a certain flavor of pumping and clipping?

9. Is my final mix going to hit digital zero and create unwanted clipping?*

So gain staging is not a single thing, but a series of choices that are made every step of the way around how you manage the "voltage" of your signals. Together these choices all add up to a mix that "breathes" well and is free of excessive or unwanted distortion.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I would rule out the Izotope production bundle (Ozone is fine). I think Izotope is the least musical and hit-or-miss of the options. It's not bad, but it's not as fun to use as the other options, and I think that has an effect on your results.

Both the FabFilter Mastering bundle and Soundtoys bundle are great and you wouldn't go wrong with either pick. But they occupy different niches: FabFilter is clean and surgical while Soundtoys is all about injecting vibe and coloration and doesn't include anything remotely surgical.

I guess if you can only pick one I'd start with Soundtoys for the vibe and the way it would expand the sonic palette for your production work. Your DAW is going to have some perfectly capable EQ's and compressors to tide you over until you're ready for FabFilter.

Put another way, your production work is upstream of your mixing work and will influence the sound of your records more.

author: Rollmottle
content:
I have a couple distinct phases of my workflow. The “technical” phase let’s call it, is all about letting my brain objectively search for the very specific kinds of things that are distracting within the mix at hand. This is much more of a thinking and corrective process than it is a feeling one, even though feeling and taste is 100% involved. This part of the process is to get the mix on a more solid foundation if needed.

The next phase is where I want to actively NOT be thinking at all. This is why I do the first part separately. I want to be FEELING the music in this phase and not be taken out of it by the vocal resonance at 1.8k at 1:35 in the bridge. I want to turn that part of my brain off so I can focus on the music, the feeling, the lyrics, the intent, the song and try to find where (or if) I can elevate or reveal or better frame the heart of what’s there. This is meant to be the flow state, moving intuitively and viscerally based on what’s coming out of the speakers. This is where efficiency in toolset matters -- where an extremely efficient human-computer interaction matters, where knowing your tools cold matters. I want to reduce latency between feeling and move and I don’t want anything to get in my way. 

So to answer your question: I think about ways to continue to be able to access and preserve that crucial flow state during the time where it matters the most. And it can manifest a million ways that aren’t directly related to mastering at all: taking a walk, working out, doing a J, listening to a new record, checking Discord, unplugging, whatever. And yes, sometimes it also means refining my template or my Streamdeck shortcuts or creating a new preset.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
i love this question. i've been doing this for long enough that the cycles of how records sound has changed several times. so every few years i try and take some time to unlearn/relearn.

there's no good short answer, but i'd start with taking some time outside of mixing to just listen to records. whether you've done this before or not, get to know your speakers and your monitoring environment better than before. listen to your favorite records that you know well, and make some tweaks. you don't necessarily have to redo your whole setup, but listen to your speakers in slightly different positions, different settings on the back of the speaker, etc. and really dig into listening and enjoy yourself.

that's usually enough to make me think about mixes very differently (which ultimately means i get better when i re-incorporate most of the things i already know). but if you need more, just try and simplify. start a mixing by just leveling everything. clip gain and leveling and panning. then balance frequencies and compress (via compressor or saturator or limiter or whatever). basically, with fresh ears, go back to basics.

not sure if that will transform you into a new mixer, but that's an outline of an approach i use when i feel like i need a big talent upgrade

author: ALXCPH
content:
1) always, always, always if possible communicate with the client. Some peeps might want you to do it from the ground up, others might just want the sound of their demo “but better”. It really depends and has no standard. 

2) starting off loud gives you less work, trying to get a finished mix loud without Changing the Sound of it. (Lets you make more “informed” decisions when building a mix if a certain loudness or Sound is your end goal). 

Ps. Mixing for real clients in a real world is never perfect and how it is imagined. Demoitis, deadlines, budgets, ego’s and so on. It’s all just about finding the best way to consistently get results. Because that’s why people hire you.

author: Zakhiggins
content:
Ive found myself getting some extra loudness recently by putting standardclip before a limiter on my group buses, not the master bus. Id use standardclip gently to just catch and even out the transients. And the limiter not to limit, but to basically gain stage post plugins. Not every bus, usually just drums and maaaybe bass or something thats very pokey. I find i can get way more out of my master bus limiter that way while keeping the dynamics.

Also standardclip is cool if u automate up the gain and down the clip on a vocal that is dynamic if you want it to distort tastefully in parts. Sounds good in shouty loud music

author: masteredbyjack
content:
From my side -- this gets down to "what is mastering even for?" territory -- but to the question at hand, it completely depends. As it must. Every project and song is different. Even on the same project, from the same mixer, it can vary widely. Mixers differ in how they deliver as well.

My opinon is mixers should take the song as far as they can, get it as close to finished as possible, this is better for the music to me. Don't even think about mastering. Then any great ME can add more x/y/z as they hear it (not always level, mastering is also about restraint). 

If you can be concerned with making the music the most itself and singular as possible, really listening for the song, you are doing the right thing. Maybe it needs to be loud, maybe not. Often it seems to me there is a misplaced focus on continuity, or a comparison to a reference, which leads me to ask...are we listening for the music anymore? Or some target that is not what we've actually made?

Just listen for what's there, and do absolutely everything you know how to do to help that. Any competent ME can take it from there, however you prefer to deliver

author: Slow Hand
content:
Neat question. If you're mixing in two channels (L/R) the headroom should be the same no matter where you pan it (with some caveats which we'll get to). If you have a kick drum panned dead center coming in at -6dB on your digital meter it's going to be coming in at -6 in both the L channel and -6 in the R channel. Each channel has it's own independent headroom that doesn't affect the other (until we add a limiter with linked channels), so let's simplify things a bit and mute the R channel for now:

Now you have your L channel with the kick panned "center" and the R channel is muted.  If you were to pan this kick to the hard left it would not affect the volume of the L channel at all. That's because the panning effect is created by subtracting gain from the R channel only. Making the kick sound like it's leaning to the left.

Now there's one big element I've left out so far, and that's *pan law*. Ableton Live has a -3dB pan law. This means that sounds panned to the center are reduced by 3dB. Because if a sound is being played at the same volume by both the L and R channels then their voltage will combine to create a sound that is louder than intended. So all DAWs and mixers compensate for this added loudness by turning down the gain of sounds as they are panned closer to the center (and shared between both speakers).

Since all modern DAWs and mixers have pan laws implemented, what happens when you now pan the kick hard left is that it ends up becoming 3dB louder than it was when it was panned in the center, because it is no longer being turned down by the pan law when it’s centered.

author: samvalentine
content:
My take away from that segment, if I'm remembering correctly, was that Jon doesn't use clip gain for 100% of his dynamic control. Instead, he carefully clip gains each transient/syllable/word/phrase into his dynamic processing (e.g., compressor, saturation, limiter), giving him precise control over how hard he hits the limiter.
I suppose another method to achieve similar results and that level of control would be to clip gain without processing, and then initiate a limiter (or your choice of dynamic processor) and automate the threshold and output to achieve the desired performance, but that seems like way more work to me.
I think Jon's method works well and I've been using it myself for a while. It would be interesting to hear of alternative workflows from the rest of the community though!

author: alex_epton
content: Do a quick balance first. With everything in. Don’t spend more than 15 mins on this. Check it on your aura tones too or whatever small alt speakers you use. Then put your two buss clipping/ limiting /any EQ you think you might need. Adjust this stuff til it sounds good and you’re hitting your target level. Get it as close as you can without touching your individual tracks. Then start dealing with little stuff on individual elements: Resonances. Masking. vocal sibilance. boomyness etc… needless to say you wanna sit down and tackle this with fresh ears. Your balance is probably the single most important thing you’re gonna do as a mixer. So do editing /cleaning clicks and vocal tuning on a different day

author: CameronKuwada
content: This is an exercise I came up with when I first started ear training: Take a bright snap (one that has freqs up to 20k) and put it in a song/beat. Make three copies of the snap track and put one snap on each track, each spaced apart equally in space. In the first, put a lowpass up to 2.5k, in the 2nd, back up lowpass to 5k, in third, back up to 10k, and in the last, no low pass. as you play this track and cycle through snaps, you'll start to hear the differences in the various ranges from 2.5k - 10k and beyond (assuming good monitoring), and also how the equal loudness curve works.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
When Jon receives a song to mix, there is almost always a lot of compression on the individual stems, especially drums and vocals. So he does more subtle moves to bring out the best in each mix. If you're recording stuff yourself, you will likely want to add a lot of compression to get the same modern, perceived loudness.

The fundamental thing to know is that "compression" simply means "reducing the dynamic range" (aka "compressing" the range of volume of your sound ). This can be achieved with "compressors" as well as "limiters," "saturators," "clippers," "distortion," and a number of other types of effects that do it in different ways (and may add other sonic characteristics to your sound).

author: Eric Martin
content:
test pressings don’t work that way, the test pressing is to determine if the cut and plating has any problems, if it does all 5 of the pressings will have the same problems in the same spots.

What you need to do is sit and listen with a notepad noting the times of the “problems” you hear, on each pressing, then if all of them have the same issue, then you have a problem with the pressing.

If you know the cutting engineer that’s the best.

My cutting engineer said, “watch sibilance and take all loudness processing off, driver at -18 and you know then you’ll have a decent vinyl master.

author: oaklandmatt
content: @sloth the reason is use clip gain is so you're not relying on the limiter or compressor to level out the sound. rather, you're using the limiter or compressor for the SOUND it creates. if you want that super compressed sound (or even that lightly compressed sound) of an actual compressor or limiter, you'll often get better results if the signal going into it is evened out a bit. this used to be solved mostly by great mic technique, where a singer would lean back on big notes and whatnot. but these days by using clip gain to even out the sound before it hits your dynamic processing, you can actually more fully lean into the SOUND of the compressor or limiter that comes after it.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Pretty much all the info above is great for general understanding. (And I do mean *great*)

To answer your other question, my personal approach usually leads me to making up 2-3db on 2buss processing. So before I instantiate and add any gain from inflators or limiters at the end of my master fader chain, I have 2-3db of headroom. 
Starting with kik snare bass around -6db, adding in vocals and everything else all balanced properly usually gets me to around -2. Which is more than enough for a mastering engineer but not enough to get myself into trouble tryna get to make it loud with my Ozone or whatever. 

That’s just my process currently. No doubt there’s different ways to get there, some likely much better, but this has been working well for my purposes.

author: Deleted User
content:
Mixing and mastering can mess up carefully crafted arrangements/recordings. In order for someone to give it a go with you, it would take some level of trust that they won’t be getting back a fucked up mix. 

I’m a producer that occasionally mix for others, and I found it the easiest to get in on earning people’s trust by offering other things first. Record them, or tune vocals for them and then let them know you also mix. People are more likely to record with someone they don’t know yet than to have someone they don’t know mix or produce their stuff.

As a producer, I’d deny free offers from new mixer to mix what I’m working on unless I have heard their work and I like them. I’ve had people ask if I need mixing and offered through their relationship with the artists- it always came back fucked… at least so far. So try to get in with producers through offering other stuff like engineering in writing sessions. Comp and tune the demo vocals you got from the writing session, if you do a great job they’ll more likely to give it a go with you. Don’t ask too early, make sure you build a good rapport with them first. Vocal tuning can fuck things up just as bad as mixing, so try to find things where you can just do it (e.g. you just recorded vocals for someone) over asking people if they need their vocals tuned.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Short answer; it’s program dependent. And everything depends on everything. 

Long answer:

I spent a long time hoping MEs would answer these questions for me, but honestly not a one of them knows wtf they’re doing. Certainly not enough to quantify things like “how much louder will I make your track.”

Best thing I did along the way was develop relationships with MEs. Usually one at a time, and worked through my questions in real time. Figured out what happened when masters come back and i felt amazing vs when they come back and I felt just ok. 

Over time I’ve developed a philosophy for myself, (and while that changes/evolves over time,) I’m now confident when I send a mix to master that what I’ll get back will be a more finished  version of my ideas. And “more finished” is not necessarily correlated to “how loud.”

author: masteredbyjack
Deleted User
content: To my ears M50s sound very congested, especially in comparison to their direct competition - Beyer 770s(I own both). The transients(which for me are absolutely crucial to hear when producing or mixing) are almost inaudible on the M50s, while decently audible on the 770s. I do not find the M50s or the 770s even close to "well balanced", they both are a bit too budget for that distinction(they both have extreme presence peaks at their respective frequencies). I know someone who is very happy with the Shure SRH940s and Shure 1840s for critical listening(same drivers, I think). The M50s and 770s are both pretty much unusable in the low end under 50-60hz for me, I don't feel they translate well there. A few mastering engineers use the Blue closed-back headphones as a low-end reference, they would probably be worth a try. Audeze stuff is pretty good for transient response, but more expensive.

author: Slow Hand
content: One question I would consider, though, is whether or not to bypass any master limiting for the live version of the track. If the mix is such that you're taking off a lot of transients on the master buss, it may sound better to ease off the limiter or bypass it entirely so that the live sound engineer will have plenty of headroom to work with and isn't trying to mix around a track that's massively limited. Having that extra headroom and transient energy could be a benefit, thought you'll have to use your ears to make that judgement, and definitely talk to the artist.

author: Slow Hand
content: It could be that the limiter is what's gluing the entire mix together and without it the track loses a certain feel. In such a case, you probably would not want to do that, if the limiter is holding it together.

author: peterlabberton
content: I’m sure you’ve read this or could find it with a quick google search, but starting with the first reflection points would be my first step. Side walls next to the listening position and ceiling above. Then probably behind the listening position and perhaps behind the speakers. If you have anything to use as a bass trap, I’d recommend using something like fuzzmeasure to shoot the room and experiment with placing that stuff in different places. You’ll be able to see peaks and valleys moving around in the low end, assuming what you’re using is actually effective at sucking up bass. There are people with much more knowledge than me, but that’s where I’d start!

author: cian riordan
content:
I would tell them there's a few things to consider when pressing vinyl:
1) Mastering is especially important as it’s the real bridge between the music and the mechanical production of the record. I had the great pleasure of mastering a few records for vinyl with Doug Sax (give him a google) and there’s a lot more to the process than modern mastering for digital services. They will actually cut the acetate disc which will be what manufacturers use to make the metal stamper that actually molds the records. A lot of thought goes into this process such as the width of the grooves to accommodate bass frequencies, etc. If you want a good sounding record, there’s no way around working with a seasoned professional.

2) Side lengths are important, as is track order. The more music you put on a side of vinyl, the less fidelity it will have as a whole. There will be sacrifices in the manufacturing to accommodate all of the music, so it’s best to keep your side lengths under 20 mins. Closer to 15 mins per side is ideal sonically, but sometimes that means doing double records and that just gets expensive. Also the order in which the tracks play on each side plays a part. The songs at the beginning of the side have more bandwidth and less distortion… it basically diminishes the closer you get to the center. Whatever the last track on the side is will just sound worse. It’s a flaw in the medium… so think about that.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Also beyond “fixing” the best thing i ever learned for drum mixing was drum bus compression, and using saturation on close mics.

My usual chain is this:
All kick and snare mics get some sort of eq if needed. Then I’ll put fab filter Saturn 2 and saturate the high end at around 700hz.

The I’ll bus all the drums to an aux. then I’ll usually do this:
Tape saturation (waves J37)
Parallel drum compression with a mix knob (fast release, slow attack) I use the kush audio AR-1, I used to use the waves abbey road mastering plugin. 

Sometimes I’ll use wavesfactory Spectre to boost highs and lows after all that. Maybe soundtoys Sie-Q to boost midrange.

author: chadwahlbrink
content: In regards to 32-bit, I try to stick with 32bit until Mastering. This is mainly out of an "abundance of caution," but basically, it's theoretically possible to have rounding errors/quantization distortion (granted at like -128dB) when bouncing between the 32-bit processing within the DAW and other processing like izotope RX or even just bouncing stems from one person to another. Note - there is also a settting in pro tools to "always use 32-bit for audiosuite processing" for this reason! Also, you can just use a 24bit dither when you go from 32 to 24bit at mastering stage as needed (if you are providing the master).

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
- **Higher sample rates reduce aliasing.** There is effectively no difference between 44.1 and 48k here but a meaningful difference at 96k and above. Aliasing is caused by non linear processes like distortion, and dynamics processing (compressor or limiter). Lots online about what it is and why it happens but you can sum it up by saying it’s an inharmonic, digital sounding hash that can feel bright but in a kind of ugly way (but remember sometimes ugly is good)
- **Higher sample rates reduce the impact of Anti Imaging and Anti Aliasing filters in AD to DA converters.** Filtering is necessary for accurate capture and replay of analog signals, and it in the early days of digital it used to be a real challenge. Now it’s basically a solved problem, but if you are doing acoustic music, with delicate transient information there is still a small but real advantage to higher rates
- **Higher sample rates reduce overshoot and inter sample peaks on limiters.** This really only matters if you are sending your loud mixes directly to release, otherwise your mastering girl or guy should handle that

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Overthinking lowers risk, but lowers potential rewards an order of magnitude more (this applies less as you get towards mastering)

author: cian riordan
content:
Sometimes gain staging is just managing the signals going to an auxiliary bus or a master fader. If you’ve got everything summing into - say - an aux bus in pro tools, and that aux bus is clipping, then that will be audible distortion going into the next gain stage. It may sound good, it probably doesn’t — so its something to account for earlier down the chain. If you’re going into a master fader in pro tools, and your signal is over 0dBFS, you can simply turn down the master fader, and it is actually turning down all the signals going to it, not just the output. This is useful because you can then throttle the input to your first plugin in the chain — say a limiter or maximizer. It’d be a shame to have a fancy clipper on your master bus, only to be clipping the signal in the chain before even getting to it.

It’s a bit of a scattershot answer to a scattershot question, but the reality is that everything affects everything in audio. And having your head wrapped around signals levels going in and out of things will help you make faster decisions and help you troubleshoot quickly when things aren’t sounding quite right.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
**General**

Interview style material can be great, and sources like Mix With The Masters where you can watch legitimate professionals working while they explain why they do what they do. Of course, you first need to understand the tools in order to understand why people use them in certain ways in specific situations, so building your knowledge of the fundamentals is important.

In general beware of anything with hyped titles like “30 MIXING HACKS I WISH I KNEW”. The internet is awash with misinformation, so it’s important to assess who the information is coming from, and what their agenda may be (whether that’s building subscribers, or shilling a product etc). If in doubt, research the records these people have worked on, and listen to them to see if you actually like how they sound!


**Engineering/Mixing/Production**

Steve Albini / Electrical Audio: https://www.youtube.com/@ElectricalAudioOfficial

Making records with Eric Valentine: https://www.youtube.com/@mrwev

Just For The Record - Mixing/interview streams - https://www.youtube.com/@JFTRLive

Sol State - Clips from longer form streams by (mostly electronic and pop) producers - https://www.youtube.com/@SolStateMusic

Live With Matt Rad (focused around Instagram Live interviews, with a generous community on Discord - generally skewing towards pop)
Insta: https://www.instagram.com/livewithmattrad/
Discord: https://discord.com/invite/fcfEtxRbWT
Podcast on Spotify, Apple Music etc.
YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/@LivewithMattRad
YouTube Clips Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCs8ZKTveuxghTN-QaHFemsw

author: cian riordan
content: Oh fuck yea, MM forever! I usually just trim the input of my final limiter (almost always the Ozone maximizer) 5dB and call it a day. All of the compression/limiting/clipping thats happening on various busses beforehand stay the same. I try to not lean on the final limiting stage to heavily in building the 'loudenss' of the mix, but I know that's not the case for everybody. If there was an instance where it was really part of the sound, I'd just leave it and send it off. Any mastering engineer worth their salt should be OK working with whatever you send them. If there are glaring issues, they're likely to bring it up... but most mixers I know don't even peel back the limiter a little... so the loudness is fully baked into the mix.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
To illustrate a good example of the difference and why (guessing) Jon would want to clip rather than do this (which would control the transients as you describe)

If you use a long look ahead, call it a limiter with a long look ahead. That will let the processor know about the transient well before it hits the GR circuit, thus avoiding distortion/harmonics (of course there still could be some artifacts). But even though there will be samples at the threshold, it won’t be a straight line waveform as if you clipped it. It is pushing the waveform down. The waveform itself is actually changed still, so it is not exact but it’s different than clipping.

A clipper just squares it off. Hence harmonics.

This is why you can limit/compress an instrument like piano, which has a tendency to hear distortion easily, when clipping it would be a disaster (unless you are going for that)
